The U.S. Senate voted 51-44 to repeal California’s plan to ban new gasoline-powered car sales by 2035, overturning a Biden-era EPA waiver that allowed stricter state-level emissions standards. The bill, backed by Republicans and industry groups, now heads to President Trump, who is expected to sign it. Critics argue the repeal undermines state authority and weakens climate efforts, while supporters claim it protects jobs and consumer choice. Democrats condemned the use of a procedural workaround that bypassed Senate rules, warning it sets a dangerous precedent. The move could reshape national clean car policies going forward.

Kraken plans to launch tokenized versions of over 50 U.S. stocks and ETFs for non-U.S. customers, starting in Europe, Latin America, Africa, and Asia. These “xStocks” will trade 24/7 on the Solana blockchain and be backed by real shares held by Kraken’s partner, Backed Finance, with tokens redeemable for the underlying securities’ cash value.
The offering includes major stocks such as Apple, Tesla, and Nvidia, as well as ETFs like the SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) and SPDR Gold Shares (GLD). U.S. customers will not have access to the service.
Kraken says xStocks aim to give international investors a cheaper, faster alternative to traditional brokerage routes, which often involve high fees and delays. The tokens may also be moved into personal digital wallets or used on other crypto platforms. Eventually, investors could even use them as collateral for crypto trading.

Country Garden Holdings has secured support from nearly 75% of its offshore bondholders for a proposed debt restructuring, according to sources familiar with the matter, ahead of a court hearing on potential liquidation next week.
To proceed under Hong Kong’s “scheme of arrangement” process, the plan requires backing from 75% of total creditors and majorities within each creditor group. While bondholder approval is nearly in place, a key group of bank creditors—the coordination committee—has not yet agreed to the proposal, the sources said.
The company faces a winding-up hearing on Monday as it seeks to finalize one of the largest restructurings by a Chinese developer since the property crisis began. Country Garden has been negotiating with offshore bondholders since defaulting over 18 months ago and is seeking to restructure $14.1 billion in debt, including $10.3 billion in bond principal, per a January filing.
The company declined to comment.

BIDU-SW (09888.HK) (BIDU.US)'s 1Q25 cloud service revenue accelerated growth by 42% YoY to RMB6.7 billion, mainly benefiting from demand from project-based enterprise clients and subscription-based enterprise clients, Citi Research issued a research report saying. After adjusting forecasts, Citi Research cut its target price from US$139 to US$138. Given the still attractive valuation, the broker kept rating at Buy.

Bitcoin continues to trade at elevated levels after reaching a record high earlier, buoyed by expectations that the U.S. will soon introduce new digital asset regulations. According to Deutsche Bank analysts in a recent note, the instability of U.S. debt has also likely contributed to Bitcoin's rise. Concerns over the high levels of U.S. government debt are intensifying as President Trump attempts to push his tax-cutting plans through Congress, following Moody's downgrade of the U.S. credit rating. This has prompted investors to seek alternatives to the dollar.

Bitcoin continues to trade at elevated levels after reaching a record high earlier, buoyed by expectations that the U.S. will soon introduce new digital asset regulations. According to Deutsche Bank analysts in a recent note, the instability of U.S. debt has also likely contributed to Bitcoin's rise. Concerns over the high levels of U.S. government debt are intensifying as President Trump attempts to push his tax-cutting plans through Congress, following Moody's downgrade of the U.S. credit rating. This has prompted investors to seek alternatives to the dollar.

CK Hutchison Holdings told investors that Italian billionaire Gianluigi Aponte’s family business is the “main investor” in the group seeking to buy its global ports, but emphasized the sale will not proceed until it secures approvals from multiple authorities. Co-managing director Dominic Lai made the comments during the company’s annual general meeting, adding the deal is subject to regulatory reviews. If approved, CK Hutchison, founded by Li Ka-Shing, will sell 43 ports—including two in Panama—to a group that also involves US investment firm BlackRock Inc.

CLSA released a research report forecasting that MEITUAN-W (03690.HK) will maintain steady performance in its core local commerce business in 1Q25, with total revenue/adjusted EBIT to grow by 17%/44% YoY to RMB85.4 billion/RMB10 billion, respectively. As intensified competition on JD Food Delivery and rapid overseas expansion could pressure future profit margins, CLSA lowered its 2025/2026 adjusted net profit forecasts for MEITUAN-W by 4%/6%, and chopped its target price from HK$217 to HK$195, with rating kept at Overweight.

OPEC+ is deliberating a potential production increase of 411,000 barrels per day for July, triple the initially planned amount, marking the third consecutive month of elevated output. The decision, to be finalized at the June 1 meeting, follows similar increases in May and June aimed at curbing quota violations and stabilizing prices.
Saudi Arabia, OPEC+’s leader, has warned overproducing members of further hikes if compliance issues persist. The group’s unexpected supply boosts, coinciding with the U.S.-China trade war in April, initially drove oil prices to a four-year low near $60 per barrel in London. However, prices have since recovered, with Brent crude trading just below $65 on Thursday as tariff tensions eased.
Despite this rebound, market sentiment remains bearish. The International Energy Agency recently forecasted slower global oil demand growth for the remainder of 2025 due to economic challenges, following a strong first quarter.

LEAPMOTOR (09863.HK)'s 1Q25 net profit improved from approximately RMB80 million in 4Q24 to about RMB130 million during the period, according to CCBI's research report. Net profit margin was 1.3%, while gross profit margin was 14.9%, approaching the upper limit of the Group's annual target of 10-15%. CCBI maintained its 2025/ 2026 sales forecasts unchanged at 504,000/ 700,000 units each, and raised its net profit forecasts to RMB388 million/ RMB1.643 billion to reflect higher production efficiency and increased overseas consumption potential driven by new models. The broker also elevated its target price from $73.2 to $86.1, with rating kept at Outperform.

Goldman Sachs continues to hold a positive view of Pony AI, primarily due to the company's significant expansion in robotaxi operations, which is supported by ongoing business enhancements and technological advancements, according to a recent analyst note. The company's robotaxi services are scaling up rapidly, with fare-charging revenue in the first quarter increasing by 800% year-over-year. This aligns with Goldman Sachs' expectations that recurring revenues will play a larger role in contributing to a more stable performance in future quarters.
Goldman Sachs believes that Pony AI's latest generation of robotaxis is likely to attract a greater number of potential users, thanks to improved cost efficiency and an expanded fleet size. As a result, Goldman Sachs has maintained its "buy" rating on Pony AI's stock and has raised its target price from $23.10 to $26.00. The stock last closed at $17.29.

Goldman Sachs is consolidating its investment banking operations across Asia Pacific into a single entity to strengthen advisory and capital markets execution. The unified APAC investment banking business will be led by Iain Drayton, who will collaborate with Yoshihiko Yano and Shogo Matsuzawa, co-heads of investment banking in Japan, and Nick Sims and Zac Fletcher, co-heads of corporate advisory in Australia and New Zealand, according to a memo confirmed by a spokesperson.

Pakistan’s Ministry of Finance has reportedly endorsed the creation of a dedicated body to regulate blockchain-based financial infrastructure in the country. The Pakistan Digital Assets Authority (PDAA) will serve as a regulatory body to oversee licensing, regulate exchanges, custodians, wallets, tokenized platforms, stablecoins and decentralized finance applications, according to a May 21 report from the state-owned broadcaster, PTV. The PDAA will also be tasked with tokenizing national assets and government debt, facilitating monetization of Pakistan’s surplus electricity through regulated Bitcoin mining, and helping startups build blockchain-based solutions at scale.

Four crypto-focused bills were introduced in the Michigan House on Wednesday, reflecting a growing state-level interest in digital asset regulation. Rep. Bill Schuette’s House Bill 4510 proposes allowing Michigan’s state treasurer to invest retirement funds in cryptocurrencies with a market cap exceeding $250 billion, effectively limiting eligibility to Bitcoin. Rep. Bryan Posthumus’ HB 4511 seeks to ban state agencies from supporting or implementing central bank digital currencies (CBDCs). Meanwhile, Rep. Mike McFall introduced HB 4512 and HB 4513, which incentivize Bitcoin mining using abandoned wells and offer tax deductions for related revenues. These efforts align with broader state initiatives to define crypto’s role in public policy.

According to Michael Brown of Pepperstone in a recent note, a prevalent issue in developed markets when it comes to addressing growing budget deficits is the short-term nature of politics. The senior research strategist explains, "The short-term nature of politics and electioneering discourages anyone from making the tough and unpalatable choices needed to put the fiscal backdrop on a more sustainable footing." He further notes that while developed market nations can borrow with ease, they will also continue to spend with the same ease.

BlackRock’s iShares Bitcoin Trust (IBIT) recorded its largest single-day inflow in two weeks on May 21, with $530.6 million added as Bitcoin surged to nearly $112,000. This marks IBIT’s biggest inflow since May 5, with no outflows since April 9. On the same day, IBIT accumulated 4,931 BTC, over 10 times the 450 BTC mined during the period. The total inflow for all 11 spot Bitcoin ETFs reached $607.1 million, with Fidelity’s fund securing $23.5 million. Analysts attribute the surge to Bitcoin’s price rally and expect further inflows.

According to a research note from Citi analysts, Baidu's advertising business is likely to drag the company's overall performance in the next few quarters. The analysts anticipate a 10% year-on-year decline in core advertising revenues in both the second and third quarters. They believe that share prices are unlikely to be re-rated before core advertising revenue returns to positive growth. While expecting the cloud margin to remain stable at a low double-digit level, the analysts note that investments in AI and disruptions to search advertising revenue will negatively impact Baidu's core operating margin in the coming quarters. Despite these challenges, the analysts maintain a buy rating, citing an attractive valuation. Citi has slightly reduced its target price for Baidu's ADRs to US$138.00 from US$139.00.

BIDU-SW (09888.HK) (BIDU.US) delivered solid 1Q25 results, with cloud business revenue growing by 42% YoY and profit margin improving QoQ to low teen level, according to a research report released by Goldman Sachs. It is expected that BIDU-SW's cloud business will maintain at least around 25% growth in 2Q25, outperforming its peers. Goldman Sachs lowered BIDU-SW's 2025-2027 EPADS by 4-6% due to profit margin pressure given a shift in revenue mix, AI investment and weaker advertising revenue, although these are partially offset by a better outlook for cloud business revenue. Therefore, the broker dropped its target prices for BIDU-SW's H-shares/US stock to $94/US$96 each, with rating kept at Buy.

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman revealed plans to staff for a revolutionary AI device developed with former Apple designer Jony Ive. The project aims to ship 100 million unobtrusive AI “companions” that integrate seamlessly into users’ lives, potentially adding $1 trillion in value to OpenAI. Unlike smartphones or wearables, the device will be aware of its surroundings and designed to reduce screen dependence. Altman emphasized the importance of stealth to prevent competitors from replicating the product prematurely. Ive described the collaboration as inspiring, likening it to his work with Steve Jobs. The $6.5 billion acquisition of Ive’s startup, io, will accelerate development, with the first device expected by late 2026. Altman envisions a “family of devices” that redefines human-AI interaction, moving beyond traditional hardware paradigms. Despite OpenAI’s financial challenges and competition from tech giants like Apple and Google, Altman sees this device as central to OpenAI’s future. He noted that existing technology fails to fully realize AI’s potential, positioning this project as a transformative step for the company and the industry.

Two members of Barclays' FICC Research team pointed out in a research report that the soaring yields of super-long Japanese Government Bonds (JGBs) reflect a structural lack of demand from the Japanese private sector. They also mentioned that position adjustments and long-term fiscal concerns could be contributing factors to the yield surge. According to them, the super-long sector is unlikely to stabilize until the structural supply-demand imbalance improves. In the absence of sufficient demand from private investors, any adjustments to the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) quantitative tightening and/or JGB issuance are likely to become the focus of attention.

JPMorgan Chase is observing a broad-based recovery in China and increased foreign investor interest in diversification, according to Rita Chan, co-senior country officer for China. Speaking at the bank’s Global China Summit in Shanghai, Chan said, “The development in the last 12 months have definitely been encouraging,” citing a rise in foreign direct investment and a recovery in liquidity and volume across the market.

From Singapore to Japan and Australia, fund managers are working with regulators to open private credit markets—once limited to institutions and ultra-wealthy clients—to retail investors, aiming to unlock billions of dollars. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is seeking public input on a proposed framework that would allow retail participation with safeguards. In Hong Kong, the industry is pushing to expand access beyond professional investors with portfolios of at least HK$8 million ($1 million), according to PwC. Japan’s Keyaki Capital has launched the country’s first online platform targeting wealthy individuals. “Private markets remain opaque to many investors,” said Hugh Chung, CIO at Endowus, citing a lack of public performance data and limited know-how as key barriers.

Gold prices are expected to gradually climb to $3,750/oz by the fourth quarter, driven by likely safe-haven demand and a weakening U.S. Dollar, according to a research report by Vivek Dhar from CBA's Global Economic & Markets Research. "The threat of military strikes against Iran cannot be ruled out, which raises the stakes if U.S.-Iran talks remain deadlocked," the analyst noted. Dhar pointed out that safe-haven demand will probably favor gold more than in the past, as the precious metal has outperformed both the USD and Treasurys following the increase in U.S. tariffs. CBA also anticipates the USD to gradually decline through the second half of 2025 and into 2026. Spot gold prices are currently 0.7% higher at $3,337.12/oz.

Many of the world’s richest family offices plan to increase investments in China despite concerns over a global trade war, according to UBS’s 2025 Global Family Office Report, which surveyed 317 family offices averaging $1.1 billion in assets. Over a third of Middle Eastern families and 39% from the Asia-Pacific region intend to boost exposure to mainland China, compared to a global average of 18%. However, none of the U.S. family offices—13% of respondents—plan to do so. The most pressing concern among these wealthy families is a global trade war, followed by geopolitical conflict and inflation.

Bitcoin surged past $110,000 for the first time, reaching $110,707 in early Asian trading on Thursday before paring gains, as traders grow increasingly bullish on its outlook. The rally is driven by optimism following the advancement of a key stablecoin bill in the U.S. Senate, boosting hopes for clearer crypto regulation. Additional momentum comes from strong demand led by Michael Saylor’s firm, which has accumulated over $50 billion in Bitcoin, along with rising interest from other digital-asset hoarders.

Investors funneled nearly $1 billion into new U.S. Bitcoin ETFs on Monday and Tuesday, with total inflows hitting $996.6 million, according to Farside Investors, helping drive Bitcoin to a record high and signaling growing market acceptance of digital assets. Net inflows into ETFs tracking Bitcoin have surged past $42 billion in recent weeks. “Bitcoin ETFs have been on fire the last few weeks,” said Bloomberg ETF research analyst James Seyffart.

Hong Kong authorities have intensified tax checks on private equity and venture funds over the past 12 to 24 months as the city seeks to address budget deficits. The Inland Revenue Department has increased scrutiny on management fees and carried interest to fund managers, prompting a surge—up to 50%—in funds seeking tax advice, according to industry consultants. “We’ve seen a noticeable increase in inquiries from fund clients seeking advice on how to deal with inquiries from the Hong Kong tax authorities in the last two years,” said Patrick Yip, vice chair at Deloitte China. While the IRD states it targets high-risk cases across all industries without singling out investment managers, it emphasized it won't interfere with carried interest arrangements as long as they are “commercially realistic” and not indicative of tax avoidance.
